STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
November 25, 2024
Keisha Taylor
VASSAR HOUSE
955 COMMERCE DR,
VASSAR, MI, 48768-8954
Re: License #: CI790296492
SI #: 2024SIC0001725
Dear Ms. Taylor:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager, Jessica VandenHeuvel at 616-204-6992.
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

Sincerely,
Stephanie S Meeuwenberg, Licensing Consultant
enclosure

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
SPECIAL INVESTIGATION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
Special Investigation #: 2024SIC0001725
Special Investigation Intake Date: August 29, 2024
License #: CI790296492
Licensee Group Organization: Wolverine Human Services
Licensee Designee: Judith Fischer
Chief Administrator: Keisha Taylor
Agency Name: VASSAR HOUSE
Agency Address: 955 COMMERCE DR
VASSAR, MI 48768-8954
License Status: Regular
License Expiration Date: 09/09/2025
Capacity: 30

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Sufficiency of staff.
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4126
Section (1) The licensee shall have a sufficient number of administrative,
Description supervisory, social service, direct care, and other staff on duty to
perform the prescribed functions required by these administrative
rules and in the agency's program statement and to provide for the
continual needs, protection, and supervision of residents.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Facility is an unsafe environment. Youth are physically assaulting
one another and sometimes this includes the use of weapons.
Youth broke into the kitchen in attempt to get knives. On 8/27/24,
male and female youth left a campsite and engaged in sexual
intercourse. They were gone for up to 8 hours without supervision.
Investigation Interviews:
The complainant was anonymous.
Director was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
September 3, 2024. Director said she is not aware of any
incidents where youth have gotten into the kitchen, got knives and
threatened each other or staff. Director said she is not aware of
youth using rocks as weapons on each other, however, there have
been incidents where youth throw rocks towards staff or property.
Director said she is not aware of any “jumping” incidents between
the youth at Vassar House.
3

Director said on August 27, 2024, Youth A, Youth B, Youth C and
Youth D ran out of unit five with Staff 1, Staff 2, and Supervisor Z
following them. Director said the staff eventually lost sight of the
youth and they were all reported AWOL. Director said staff
resumed searching in the morning where they found the youth in
an empty cabin at camp three.
Youth A was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
September 3, 2024. Youth A denied any youth being jumped,
youth fighting with rocks or knives, or staff allowing any assaults.
Youth A said staff always intervene and stop youth if they become
physically aggressive.
Youth A said she and Youth B, Youth C, and Youth D ran on and
off the units all day on August 27, 2024. Youth A said staff followed
them each time and told them to go back to the units. Youth A said
when they left at night the staff followed for “a while” and then
stopped, denying any youth threatening to knock down staff or
take their phones. Youth A said she and her peers climbed into an
empty cabin through a broken window and “hung out” until 8am
when they were found by staff. Youth A said she does not believe
staff knew where the youth had gone.
Youth B was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
September 3, 2024, and face-to-face at the facility on
September 18, 2024, in collaboration with MDHHS worker.
Youth B denied knowing any youth that have broken into the
kitchen and retrieved knives and threatened one another. Youth B
denied youth using rocks as weapons against each other however
noted she has witnessed youth throwing rocks at staff multiple
times. Youth B denied the youth fighting or jumping one another at
Vassar House. Youth B reported an incident when she, Youth C,
and Youth D, along with Clarence Fischer Center youth were
knocking on the unit door where Youth E was located to get her to
come outside. Youth B said Youth E had been “telling stories”
about her, Youth C, and Youth D as well as the Clarence Fischer
Center youth and they all wanted to resolve the lies she was
spreading. Youth B said they got the unit door opened, and she
began to hit Youth E over staff through the door. Youth B said the
staff got the door closed but then Youth E came running out the
back door and into the parking lot area. Youth B said Youth C
began to fight Youth E for less than a minute as staff intervened
and separated them. Youth B said the staff never allowed anyone
to fight and there were many staff around them telling them to stop
and physically separating them. Youth B denied staff holding Youth
4

E while the other youth hit her, stating staff “never allow” them to
fight.
Youth B said she and her peers have walked out of the units many
times and staff always follow them around. Youth B said she left
the unit on August 27, 2024, with Youth A, Youth C, and Youth D
and Staff 1 and Staff 2 followed them for “a while”. Youth B said
Staff 1 and Staff 2 stopped following them “at some point” and the
youth went to an empty cabin at camp three and “hung out”. Youth
B said staff found them the next day around 7am. Youth B said
she does not believe the staff knew where she and the other youth
had gone that night.
Youth C refused to be interviewed on September 3, 2024, and
provided limited information on September 11, 2024, in
collaboration with MDHHS worker. Youth C said Youth E came
out of the unit to fight and “got beat up”. Youth C said there were
no youth trying to get into the unit. Youth C said she does not
know who was involved in the fight besides her. Youth C said staff
were present, however she did not remember who. Youth C said
staff do not allow the youth to fight and do what they can to stop
them.
Youth C refused to answer questions regarding leaving the unit on
August 27, 2024, stating she “already talked to someone about it”.
Youth C reported that “all staff” knew where the youth were at on
the night of August 27, 2024, because they “had on all the lights
and were loud as hell”. Youth C denied any of the youth making
statements about getting rid of the staff or taking their phones.
Youth C said Staff 1 and Staff 2 stopped following the youth
because it started to rain.
Youth D was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
September 3,2024, and face-to-face at the facility on
September 18, 2024, in collaboration with MDHHS worker.
Youth D said she has not witnessed or heard of youth threatening
each other with knives, jumping one another, or throwing rocks at
each other, however, has seen youth throw rocks at staff. Youth D
said there was a situation where she, Youth B, Youth C, and some
Clarence Fischer Center youth knocked on the door of Youth E’s
unit telling her to come outside because she had been talking
“crap” about all of them. Youth D said Youth E came outside and
Youth B and Youth C tried to fight her, but staff intervened and
stopped the fight. Youth D said she was never able to make
physical contact with Youth E. Youth D said staff never allow the
youth to fight and always intervene.
5

Youth D said she was one of the youth that left the unit on August
27, 2024, around midnight. Youth D said it was not planned but
once Youth A ran the others followed. Youth D said Supervisor Z
told the youth that if they run off the unit, they could not come back
into the unit. Youth D said she “just walked around campus” with
Youth A, Youth B, and Youth C. Youth D said some of the youth
came out of Clarence Fischer Center and they all walked around
together. Youth D said Staff 1 and Staff 2 followed her and the
other youth for “a while” and then were told to stop following by
Supervisor Z. Youth D denied any youth making statements about
harming the staff or taking their cellphones, however, said the
youth from Clarence Fischer Center made statements about the
Vassar youth not walking with them if Staff 1 and Staff 2 were
going to keep following them. Youth D said once Staff 1 and Staff
2 stopped following them, the youth all went to an empty cabin
that two other Clarence Fischer Center youth had open and
“chilled”. Youth D said the Clarence Fischer Center youth were “in
and out” of the cabin throughout the night. Youth D said she took a
bed out of a room and slept on it in kitchen with another youth.
Youth D said staff found her in the cabin around 7am the following
morning. Youth D said this was the one and only time she was out
of her unit all night.
Youth E was interviewed via TEAMS on October 10, 2024, in
collaboration with MDHHS worker. Youth E said she was placed
at Vassar House and is now home with her mother. Youth E said
prior to leaving Vassar House there was an incident when Youth B,
Youth C, Youth D, one other Vassar House youth, and “six”
Clarence Fischer Center youth came to her unit pounding on the
door trying to fight with her. Youth E said the youth were able to
get the door open, but Staff 6 was able to keep the youth out and
secure the door. Youth E said she left out the back door and Staff
7 followed her. Youth E said she went to the parking lot in front of
Vassar House and fought with Youth B, Youth C, and Youth D
while the Clarence Fischer Center youth watched. Youth E said
there were “a bunch” of staff present and were stopping the youth
from fighting and separating them. Youth E said Director took
ahold of her and brought her back into her unit. Youth E said the
police had been called and were present as well. Youth E denied
the staff holding her so the other youth could punch her. Youth E
said the staff never allow the youth to fight and always intervene in
all verbal and physical altercations.
Staff 1 was interviewed via telephone on September 3, 2024.
Staff 1 said she is not aware of youth jumping one youth, having
6

or threatening each other with knives or rocks. Staff 1 said when
she came into her shift on August 27, 2024, the youth had already
been having a rough day, not following programming. Staff 1 said
Youth D pulled a walkie out of her bra said something into it and
the Clarence Fischer Center youth responded, and she shoved it
back into her bra. Staff 1 said Youth A, Youth B, Youth C, and
Youth D walked out of the unit and she and Staff 2 followed them.
Staff 1 said the youth walked over to Clarence Fischer Center
where a youth let them into the building. Staff 1 said Staff 2 was
able to get in with the youth however someone then shut the door,
so she was not able to get in and ran around the building to go
through another door. Staff 1 said once she got to the other side of
the building a supervisor from Clarence Fischer Center was
coming out stating the youth all ran out of the building. Staff 1 said
she was able to catch up with Staff 2 and the youth where she
followed for “hours”. Staff 1 said two of the Clarence Fischer
Center youth began to make statements to Youth A, Youth B,
Youth C, and Youth D about “getting rid of staff” and Staff 1 said
the youth said they were going to grab staff feet and knock them
over and grab their cellphones and run. Staff 1 said she called
Supervisor Z and explained to him what the youth said as well as
telling him that they were overgrown grass and there were no
lights besides the flashlights from their cellphones. Staff 1 said
Supervisor Z directed her and Staff 2 to stop following the youth
and come back to the unit as it became a safety issue. Staff 1
denied any youth returning to the units while she was on shift.
Staff 1 said the youth were found at 8:30am the following day.
Staff 1 said once the youth returned Supervisor Z did tell the youth
they had to be searched prior to returning to their units.
Staff 2 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
September 3, 2024. Staff 2 said she has never seen youth break
into the kitchen or have access to knives. Staff 2 said she has
never seen youth harm each other with rocks or situations where
one youth is being “jumped” by several other youth. Staff 2 said
any situations she has seen or been involved in with youth
physical fighting with each other staff always intervene and do
everything they are able to stop the fighting and keep youth safe.
Staff 2 said she was working the night of August 27, 2024. Staff 2
said when she arrived at work the youth were already having a
rough day and not following the program rules. Staff 2 said Youth
A was on the unit and not supposed to be and after being told to
go to unit one she went in the bathroom and took a shower, got
dressed and began to whisper to Youth B, Youth C, and Youth D.
Staff 2 said Youth A told staff she would go to her unit and Youth
7

B, Youth C and Youth D said they would walk Youth A to her unit.
Staff 2 said Youth B, Youth C, and Youth D were told not to leave
the unit with Youth A however they all did anyways. Staff 2 said
one of the youth had a walkie talkie and pulled it out of her bra
and began to talk to the youth from Clarence Fischer Center on it.
Staff 2 said she and Staff 1 followed the youth as they went over
to Clarence Fischer Center and got into one of the units. Staff 2
said she was able to get into the unit with the youth and was
redirecting Youth A, Youth B, Youth C, and Youth D to leave and
head back to Vassar House. Staff 2 said one of the youths
grabbed a jacket from the Clarence Fischer Center youth and they
all headed outside towards the gym. Staff 2 said all the lights were
off in the gym so she called the police and turned on the lights to
search for the youth. Staff 2 said they found Youth A, Youth B, and
Youth D in a small room however Youth C had run outside with the
youth from Clarence Fischer Center. Staff 2 said once she and
Staff 1 found Youth A, Youth B, and Youth D they ran outside once
again and began to walk around the property. Staff 2 said
Supervisor Z stayed at the gym to talk to the police who had
arrived. Staff 2 said the youth all began to run through the woods
where there were no lights and long grass. Staff 2 said the youth
from Clarence Fischer Center started to make comments to Youth
A, Youth B, Youth C, and Youth D regarding “getting rid of staff”
and talked about knocking her and Staff 1 to the ground and
taking their cellphones as that was the only light they had in the
woods. Staff 2 said she contacted Supervisor Z and reported the
situation and was directed to return to Vassar House as it has
become unsafe. Staff 2 said she felt she followed the youth for as
long as possible and they had no intention of returning to the unit.
Staff 2 said she followed for approximately three to four hours
prior to returning to Vassar house. Staff 2 denied the youth trying
to return to the unit. Staff 2 said the youth had been told they
would need to be searched upon their return but were never told
not to come back to the unit.
Staff 6 was interviewed via telephone on September 30, 2024,
in collaboration with MDHHS worker. Staff 6 denied the youth
ever getting into the kitchen or having knives as weapons. Staff 6
said there have been some fighting among youth at the facility and
staff always intervene and stop the youth. Staff 6 said he was
working with Youth E when Youth B, Youth C, Youth D, and some
Clarence Fischer Center youth knocked on the door and
attempted to get in the unit. Staff 6 said he was able to secure the
front door and prevent the youth from entering the unit however
stated Youth E then ran out the back door instead. Staff 6 said
Staff 7 followed Youth E outside while he remained on the unit with
8

another youth. Staff 6 said he did not witness what occurred
outside during that incident however noted that Youth E was back
in the unit within 15 minutes.
Staff 6 said he was working on August 27, 2024, when Youth A,
Youth B, Youth C, and Youth D all went AWOL from the facility.
Staff 6 said he remained on the unit and Staff 1 and Staff 2
followed the youth. Staff 6 said at no point did the youth return and
ask to come back to the unit. Staff 6 said Staff 1 and Staff 2
followed “for a long time” and when they returned they said it was
due to a safety issue. Staff 6 said whenever youth run off the unit
a staff member follows them.
Staff 7 was interviewed via telephone on October 10, 2024, in
collaboration with MDHHS worker. Staff 7 said she was working
with Youth B, Youth C, Youth D, and four youth from Clarence
Fischer Center were all pounding on the unit door trying to get to
Youth E. Staff 7 said Staff 6 was in the unit with her and was able
to secure the door so that the youth were not able to get into the
unit. Staff 7 said Youth E then ran out the back door of the unit and
she followed her. Staff 7 said Youth E went into the parking lot
area however Director was able to intercept her before she
actually began fighting with her peers. Staff 7 said there were
several staff outside during that incident following the Clarence
Fischer Center youth as well as Youth B, Youth C, and Youth D.
Staff 7 said the staff always intervene in all verbal and physical
altercations and never allow the youth to fight.
Supervisor Z was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
September 3, 2024. Supervisor Z said he has never seen or
heard of youth getting knives and threatening one another.
Supervisor Z said he has never heard or seen youth using rocks
as weapons towards other youth however has seen youth throw
rocks at the building and staff.
Supervisor Z said when he arrived on August 27, 2024, he was
dealing with another peer for a short time and then went to unit
five due to there being five youth on the unit and there only
supposed to be four youth. Supervisor Z said he was trying to get
Youth A to move from unit five to unit one however she continued
to refuse so he left the unit and went to talk to Supervisor Y to
develop a plan. Supervisor Z said after talking to Supervisor Y and
Director it was determined that Youth A needed to go to unit one
as that was where her belongings were located and that was her
unit. Supervisor Z said he went back on unit five and Youth A
continued to refuse to go to unit one. Supervisor Z said Supervisor
9

Y walked into unit five and “grabbed” Youth A’s arms “kinda
aggressively” and began to walk with her to the door. Supervisor Z
said Youth A was willingly walking with Supervisor Y at first.
Supervisor Z said he walked around Youth A and Supervisor Y let
go of one of Youth A’s arms so he took that arm and Youth A
immediately dropped to the ground and so he released Youth A.
Supervisor Z said Supervisor Y did not release right away but
denied seeing Supervisor Y drag Youth A in any manner.
Supervisor Z said Youth A then stood up and ran into the
bathroom and started talking off all her clothing. Supervisor Z said
he and Supervisor Y then left the unit due to Youth A undressing.
Supervisor Z said Youth A began to accuse Supervisor Y of
smelling like alcohol however Supervisor Z said he did not smell
any alcohol on Supervisor Y. Supervisor Z said he did not have
concerns about Supervisor Y’s behaviors or concerns that he was
intoxicated. Supervisor Z said he went back to unit five after staff
reported Youth A was out of the bathroom and dressed.
Supervisor Z said Youth B, Youth C, and Youth D said Youth A was
willing to go to unit one and they were going to walk her to the
unit. Supervisor Z said he told Youth B, Youth C and Youth D that
they were not to walk Youth A to unit one however they all walked
outside anyways. Supervisor Z said once outside Youth C pulled a
walkie talkie out of her bra and began to talk to the Clarence
Fischer Center youth. Supervisor Z said Youth C then gave the
walkie talkie to Youth D who also was talking to the Clarence
Fischer Center youth, making statements about having them
come outside to meet up with her, Youth A, Youth B, and Youth C.
Supervisor Z said Youth A, Youth B, Youth C, and Youth D walked
to Clarence Fischer Center and a youth let them into the Clarence
Fischer Center building and gave them jackets. Supervisor Z said
Youth A, Youth B, Youth C and Youth D all then left the building
with the Clarence Fischer Center youth and walked over to the
gym. Supervisor Z said all of the youth went into the gym and the
police arrived to assist in the situation. Supervisor Z said the
police said they could not do anything to help as all the youth were
still on campus. Supervisor Z said all the youth then walked out of
the gym and were walking around the campus with himself, Staff 1
and Staff 2 following them. Supervisor Z said he was in a car
following when the youth, Staff 1, and Staff 2 all went down a
sidewalk. Supervisor Z said he received a phone call from Staff 2
that the youth were walking towards camp three and began
making threats about knocking the staff down and taking their cell
phones. Supervisor Z said due to the area the staff were in, the
lack of lights, and the threats by the youth, he directed Staff 1 and
Staff 2 to return to Vassar House. Supervisor Z said he brought
Staff 1 and Staff 2 back to Vassar House and then began
10

searching for the youth however never found them. Supervisor Z
said he resumed the search around 7:30am with other staff and
the youth were found in Bison Cabin on Camp 3. Supervisor Z
said Youth A, Youth B, Youth C and Youth D came back to Vassar
House and he told them they had to be searched prior to going
back into the unit. Supervisor Z said Youth A and Youth D refused
searches at first but finally agreed to be searched. Supervisor Z
said he never told the youth they were not allowed to come back
into the unit. Supervisor Z said the youth never came back to
Vassar House throughout the night asking to come back into the
unit. Supervisor Z said he did not know that the youth were at
camp three until the next morning.
Supervisor Y was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
September 18, 2024, in collaboration with MDHHS worker.
Supervisor Y said youth have thrown rocks at staff, windows, and
cars but never at each other. Supervisor Y said he has never
heard of youth having knives as weapons. Supervisor Y said he
has never heard or seen staff allow youth to fight and always
intervene to keep youth safe.
Supervisor Y said he came into work to assist on August 27, 2024,
from 7pm until 4:30am. Supervisor Y said Youth A, Youth B, Youth
C, and Youth D all ran off the unit and were running around
campus for most of the night. Supervisor Y said Staff 1 and Staff 2
were following them around on foot and he and Supervisor Z were
in the car looking for them. Supervisor Y said sometime around
3am Staff 2 called and said the youth threatened to beat her and
Staff 1 up so directed them back to the facility due to safety
concerns. Supervisor Y said at that time the youth were in the
woods where it was dark and were continuing to head further
away from the units. Supervisor Y said he and Supervisor Z
continued to follow for a period of time, but they lost sight of the
youth and therefore returned to the facility and completed the
AWOL paperwork. Supervisor Y said he felt the staff did all they
were able to do to follow and try to get the youth back to their
units.
Video Reviewed:
Video footage of August 28, 2024, 12:16am back door to unit five
at Clarence Fischer Center was reviewed. Youth A, Youth B, Youth
C, Youth D, and Staff 2 are all seen walking out the back door in a
group. Staff 2 is seen with her cell phone up to her ear.
There was no other video footage of the August 28, 2024, AWOL
incident.
11

Documents Reviewed:
• Wolverine Human Services Truancy Policy and Procedure
was reviewed. The policy states if “non-supervising staff is
available, they will walk with the client and continue to
provide verbal support and redirection encouraging the
client not to truant”. In addition, the policy states “Staff will
immediately notify the Youth Care Specialist Supervisor on
duty when line of sight is lost, no later than 15 from loss of
line of sight (when youth is determined AWOL).”
• Wolverine Human Services Line of Sight Policy was
reviewed. The policy states staff are to “maintain adequate
supervision coverage and “line of sight” of all clients when
in direct supervision of clients. Within the line of sight
means that it is possible to reasonably visually distinguish
and recognize individuals.”
• Wolverine Human Services Policy and Procedure for CPI in
Residential Programs. The policy outlines the expectations
for staff to intervene in “any behavior that is likely to result
in physical injury or imminent risk of physical harm of the
client, other clients, staff members, or others”.
• Wolverine Human Services Incident Reports dated August
27, 2024, regarding Youth A, Youth B, Youth C and Youth D
were reviewed. The incident reports indicated the time the
youth AWOLed from the facility, staff’s response of following
and encouraging them to return to their unit and losing line
of sight in the woods near camp three and reporting the
youth AWOL. The incident report is consistent with Staff 1
and Staff 2’s interview.
Analysis The agency is found in compliance as per staff and youth
interviews, documentation review, and video review it is
determined staff are followed youth when they went AWOL on
August 27, 2024, until it became unsafe. In addition, staff are
intervening with youth argue and become physically aggressive
protecting them from harm from one another.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code Staff to resident ratio
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4127
Section (1) The licensee shall develop and adhere to a written staff-to-
Description resident ratio formula for direct care workers.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
12

Allegation Facility is an unsafe environment. The ratio is off compromising
supervision and causing kitchen staff and other staff that don't
work with children to assist.
Investigation Interviews:
The complainant was anonymous.
Director was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
September 3, 2024. Director said Vassar is scheduled with
enough staff to maintain ratio and no extra staff at this time.
Director said to her knowledge the staff have remained in ratio
unless a youth runs off the unit and a staff follows the youth, which
may leave the staff back on the unit out of ratio. Director said the
staff will make an assessment at the time of the incident to
determine the greater safety risk, either leaving unit with one staff
and three youth or following the youth that ran off the unit.
Director said there have not been any kitchen staff working directly
with the youth. Director said the maintenance staff have not
assisted with Vassar House youth. Director said Staff 3 is a
cleaning staff however has picked up a shift and worked directly
with the youth in Vassar House. Director said all staff receive the
same background checks and training as a direct care staff.
Youth A was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
September 3, 2024. Youth A said she is on a unit with one other
youth and there are always two staff working on the unit with
them. Youth A said there have never been any kitchen or
maintenance staff working her unit as a direct care staff.
Youth B was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
September 3, 2024. Youth B said she is aware the ratio is one
staff for every two youth during the day and one staff for every four
youth at night. Youth B denied ever knowing a time when the staff
were out of ratio. Youth B said Staff 3 has worked on the unit with
the youth, however she reported she has never seen any kitchen
staff or maintenance staff working the units.
Youth C refused to be interviewed on September 3, 2024, and
provided limited information on September 11, 2024, in
collaboration with MDHHS worker. Youth C said staff are
“sometimes” in ratio and “sometimes” they are not, however would
not elaborate on this information. Youth C said she “did not know”
who works on her unit.
Youth D was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
September 3, 2024. Youth D said she in on a unit with three other
youth and there are always two staff members working with them.
13

Youth D said there are times when a youth will leave the unit and
one of the staff follow the youth, leaving the other staff with three
youth. Youth D said at night there is one staff with all four youth.
Youth D said there have only been direct care staff working with
her unit, denying having kitchen or maintenance staff working with
her.
Staff 1 was interviewed via telephone on September 3, 2024.
Staff 1 said she works third shift, and the ratio is one staff to four
youth. Staff 1 said the units only have four youth so she normally
works alone, and a supervisor will make rounds for breaks and to
check in with staff. Staff 1 denied being out of ratio on any of her
shifts. Staff 1 said she has never seen or heard kitchen or
maintenance staff working the units at Vassar House.
Staff 2 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
September 3, 2024. Staff 2 said she works third shift, where the
ratio is one staff to four youth. Staff 2 said there are only four
youth per unit and therefore always within ratio during her shift.
Staff 2 said there are times when they will even have two staff on
a unit at night. Staff 2 said she has not seen or heard of kitchen or
maintenance staff working on the units however was aware of
maintenance staff keeping line-of-sight when youth run out of the
unit until another staff was able to come out or catch up to the
youth. Staff 2 said during those times when maintenance staff kept
line-of-sight they did not intervene with the youth.
Staff 6 was interviewed via telephone on September 30, 2024,
in collaboration with MDHHS worker. Staff 6 said the facility is a
one staff to two youth ratio and he has never worked out of that
ratio unless there is a one-on-one youth at which time they have
more than ratio requires. Staff 6 denied any untrained staff
working the units, noting Staff 3 has worked units and normally
does the cleaning however said she is trained to work as a direct
staff.
Supervisor Y was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
September 18, 2024, in collaboration with MDHHS worker.
Supervisor Y said staff are all scheduled to be within ratio however
there are times when a staff is late so a supervisor will sit on the
unit, or a youth runs off the unit and a staff determines it is safe to
leave one staff with three youth and follow the youth that ran out.
Supervisor Y said Staff 3 is normally a cleaning staff but has
worked units at Vassar House.
14

Supervisor Z was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
September 3, 2024. Supervisor Z said the staff schedule always
has enough staff to maintain ratio in each unit, with one staff for
two youth during the day and one staff for four youth at nighttime.
Supervisor Z said there have been times when the units are out of
ratio due to the youth running off the unit and staff following
leaving one staff with three youth. Supervisor Z said each incident
is determined in the moment to determine which is the greater
safety concern. Supervisor Z said he is not aware of any kitchen
or maintenance staff that have worked the units in ratio however
stated Staff 3 has worked the unit and normally does the cleaning
at the facility.
Documents Reviewed:
• Staff 3’s personnel file was reviewed. Staff 3 had the
required background checks completed prior to hire. Staff 3
participated in onboarding that aligns with a direct care
staff, including but not limited to all policies and procedures,
restraint training, and line of sight requirements.
• Vassar House Program Statement dated November 6,
2023, was reviewed. The program statement said the “Staff
to Client ratio is 1 to 2 clients.”
Analysis The agency is found in non-compliance as per the staff and youth
interviews, the staff work one staff to four youth at night and there
have been times when they have left three youth with one staff in
order to follow a youth who walks out of the facility without
permission.
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE:
Technical assistance was offered to create a policy outlining
sleeping and awake hours to ensure clear ratio expectations.
Ratio is not to be contingent on when a staff arrive or leave work.
Conclusion Repeat Violation Established
SIR 2024SIC0001814 dated 11/22/24, CAP pending
Rule Code Incident reporting
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4150
Section (3) If an institution determines that a youth is absent without legal
Description permission, then the institution shall immediately report the
information to law enforcement, the parent/legal guardian or next
of kin, the licensing authority, and the referring agency.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
15

Allegation Parents for youth that went AWOL on August 27, 2024, were not
notified.
Investigation Interviews:
Parent 4 was interviewed via telephone on September 9, 2024,
in collaboration with MDHHS worker. Parent 4 said she is the
mother of Youth A. Parent 4 said she participated in a court
hearing for Youth A on August 28, 2024, in the morning. Parent 4
said at the beginning of court Youth A’s attorney asked Youth A
how she was doing at Vassar House to which she responded
“good”. Parent 4 said Staff 4 then “peeked” her head on the
camera and stated that was not true and Youth A had just returned
to the facility this morning after being AWOL all night long. Parent
4 said that was the first notification she had received regarding the
AWOL.
Parent 1 was interviewed via telephone on September 12,
2024, by MDHHS worker. Parent 1 said she is the mother to
Youth D. Parent 1 said she was informed at court at 9am on
August 28, 2024, about Youth D being AWOL the night prior.
Parent 2 was interviewed via telephone on September 5, 2024,
by MDHHS worker. Parent 2 said she is the mother of Youth B.
Parent 2 said she was told by the facility that Youth B was gone
for several hours with other youth from the facility.
Parent 3 was interviewed via telephone on September 9, 2024,
by MDHHS worker. Parent 3 said she is the mother of Youth C.
Parent 3 said she was called and made aware of the AWOL by the
Vassar House staff on August 28, 2024. Parent 3 said she was
very concerned about Youth C being gone that long without staff
supervision.
Documents Reviewed:
• Wolverine Human Services Truancy and AWOL policy was
reviewed. Staff are expected to make notifications to
“Parents/Guardian (immediately)” after “a client truants
from WHS property”.
• Wolverine Human Services Critical Incident Response and
Reporting Procedures was reviewed. The policy outlines
AWOL as a critical incident however there is no expectation
in the policy for notification to parents.
• Wolverine Human Services Social Work Contacts were
reviewed. The following contacts regarding the AWOL
notification were viewed:
16

o Youth A parent notification dated August 28, 2024.
The note stated Parent 4 was notified of the AWOL
at Youth A’s court hearing.
o Youth B parent notification dated August 28, 2024.
The note stated a call to Parent 2.
o Youth C parent notification dated August 28, 2024.
The note stated a call to Parent 3.
o Youth D parent notification dated August 28, 2024.
The note stated Parent 1 was notified of the AWOL
at Youth A’s court hearing.
Analysis The agency is found in non-compliance as per parent interviews
and review of the agency contacts, none of the parents were
notified of the youth’s AWOL immediately.
CONSULTATION:
It is recommended that the agency update the Critical incident
Response and Reporting Procedure to include notifications to
parents, as well as update the timeframes for the notifications to
ensure they meet the licensing rule requirements.
Conclusion Violation Established
Rule Code Health services; policies and procedures.
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4142
Section (1) An institution shall establish and follow written health service
Description policies and procedures addressing all of the following:
(e) Dispensing medication.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth was given medications without the consent of parent.
Investigation Interviews:
Parent 4 was interviewed September 9, 2024, in collaboration
with MDHHS worker. Parent 4 said she is the mother of Youth A.
Parent 4 said Youth A recently moved to Wayne Juvenile
Detention Facility and upon arrival Parent 4 was told she had
been prescribed Seroquel while at Vassar House. Parent 4 said
she never gave permission for Youth A to be given Seroquel.
Documents Reviewed:
• Youth A’s medical records from Vassar House were
reviewed. Youth A most recent appointment with the
psychiatrist was on August 5, 2024. As of that date Youth
A’s list of prescribed medications did not include Seroquel.
17

• Youth A’s Medication Administration Record for August
2024 and September 2024 were reviewed. Youth A did not
have Seroquel on her list of medications and was never
administered Seroquel at Vassar House.
• Wolverine Human Services Psychotropic Medication
Consent Protocol for Residential Services was reviewed.
The policy states “All WHS residential clients must have an
authorized consent for administration of psychotropic
medications present and in medical case file. Authorized
consent must be provided in writing, on an approved
consent form, by the client’s legal guardian.”
• Wolverine Human Services Medication Control
Administration Policy and Site Protocols was reviewed. The
policy outlines the staff allowed to administer the
medications must be trained and only mediations on the
Medication Administration Record are to be administered to
the youth.
Analysis The agency is found in compliance as per the medical records for
Youth A she was never prescribed or administered Seroquel.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code Intervention standards and prohibitions
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4158
Section (1) A child caring institution shall establish and follow written
Description policies and procedures that prohibit the following forms of
intervention:
(a) Any type of physical punishment including, but not limited to:
(ii) Hitting or striking, throwing, kicking, pulling, or pushing a
youth on any part of their body.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Staff dragged a youth across the floor when attempting to remove
her from the unit.
Investigation Youth A was interviewed face-to-face at Wayne County
Juvenile Detention Center by DHHS worker and DCWL
Consultant on September 11, 2024. Youth A said she was on
unit five without permission and Supervisor Y came onto the unit,
walked over to her “grabbed” her arm, and “dragged” her across
the floor. Youth A said Supervisor Y was holding her by the arm
and the rest of her body was on the ground. Youth A said
Supervisor Z was also present but was not doing anything about
the situation. Youth A said Youth D told Supervisor Y to stop and
pushed him away from her. Youth A said Youth C, Youth B and
18

Youth F were also present and saw the incident. Youth A said
Supervisor Y smelled strongly of liquor. Youth A said this was the
only time she smelled alcohol on Supervisor Y. Youth A said she
wrote a grievance and provided it to Staff 4 and Staff 5.
Youth D was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
September 3,2024. Youth D said the evening of August 27, 2024,
prior to the AWOL, Youth A was “dragged” by Supervisor Y. Youth
D said Youth A was on unit five and was supposed to go to unit
one but did not want to. Youth D said Supervisor Y came into the
unit, walked over to Youth A, “grabbed her”, and began to drag her
towards the door. Youth D said she saw Supervisor Y doing this
and stopped Supervisor Y by grabbing his arms off her. Youth D
said Youth A told her Supervisor Y smelled like alcohol, but Youth
D denied smelling any alcohol on Supervisor Y. Youth D said
Supervisor Y appeared very angry and stressed out when he
entered the unit.
Staff 1 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
September 18, 2024, in collaboration with MDHHS worker.
Staff 1 said Youth A was refusing to leave unit five and return to
unit one. Staff 1 said Supervisor Z and Supervisor Y entered the
unit and directed Youth A to go to unit one and took her by the
arms and began to walk her out of unit five. Staff 1 said Youth A
began to kick her feet and swing, so they released her, and she
ran into the shower and undressed. Staff 1 said Supervisor Y was
guiding Youth A and she did not feel it was aggressive in nature.
Staff 1 said she never saw Supervisor Y drag Youth A at any point.
Staff 1 said she has not seen Supervisor Y being aggressive
towards any youth. Staff 1 said she did not smell alcohol on
Supervisor Y that night or any other night she has worked with
him. Staff 1 said Supervisor Y did not have any concerning
behaviors and she did not believe he was intoxicated.
Staff 2 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
September 3, 2024. Staff 2 said she was working the night of
August 27, 2024. Staff 2 said when she arrived at work there were
five youth in her unit when there was only supposed to be four.
Staff 2 said Youth A was asked to leave the unit and return to her
own unit however refused. Staff 2 said Supervisor Y entered the
unit and asked Youth A to leave and she laughed at him and said
no. Staff 2 said Supervisor Y then attempted to escort Youth A out
of the unit and she dropped to the floor, so he released her. Staff 2
said Youth A got up and ran into the bathroom and undressed so
that staff were unable to touch her. Staff 2 said the Supervisor Y
then left the unit.
19

Staff 6 was interviewed via telephone on September 30, 2024,
in collaboration with MDHHS worker. Staff 6 said he was
working on unit five on August 27, 2024, when Youth A refused to
return to her unit. Staff 6 said Supervisor Y came onto the unit and
tried to assist Youth A out of the unit by “pulling her arm” to where
she needed to go, but she sat on the floor and so Supervisor Y
backed up. Staff 6 denied seeing Supervisor Y drag Youth A. Staff
6 denied smelling alcohol on Supervisor Y or noticing any
difference in his behaviors.
Supervisor Z was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
September 3, 2024. Supervisor Z said when he arrived on August
27, 2024, he was dealing with another peer for a short time and
then went to unit five due to there being five youth on the unit and
there only supposed to be four youth. Supervisor Z said he was
trying to get Youth A to move from unit five to unit one however
she continued to refuse so he left the unit and went to talk to
Supervisor Y to develop a plan. Supervisor Z said after talking to
Supervisor Y and Director it was determined that Youth A needed
to go to unit one as that was where her belongings were located
and that was her unit. Supervisor Z said he went back on unit five
and Youth A continued to refuse to go to unit one. Supervisor Z
said Supervisor Y walked into unit five and “grabbed” Youth A’s
arms “kinda aggressively” and began to walk with her to the door.
Supervisor Z said Youth A was willingly walking with Supervisor Y
at first. Supervisor Z said he walked around the tables to Youth A
at which time Supervisor Y let go of one of Youth A’s arms so he
took that arm and Youth A immediately dropped to the ground and
so he released. Supervisor Z said Supervisor Y did not release
right away but denied seeing Supervisor Y drag Youth A in any
manner. Supervisor Z said Youth A then stood up and ran into the
bathroom and started talking off all her clothing. Supervisor Z said
he and Supervisor Y then left the unit due to Youth A undressing.
Supervisor Z said Youth A began to accuse Supervisor Y of
smelling like alcohol however Supervisor Z said he did not smell
any alcohol on Supervisor Y. Supervisor Z said he did not have
concerns about Supervisor Y’s behaviors or concerns that he was
intoxicated. Supervisor Z has never had concerns with the
interactions between Supervisor Y and any youth.
Supervisor Y was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
September 18, 2024, in collaboration with MDHHS worker.
Supervisor Y said he was helping at the facility on August 27,
2024, however, was not actually scheduled to work. Supervisor Y
said he was called down to unit five because Youth A was in the
20

unit and was not supposed to be as her unit was unit one.
Supervisor Y said he asked Youth A to go to her unit and she said
no. Supervisor Y said he then put his hand on Youth A’s back to
escort her out of unit five. Supervisor Y said Youth A was walking
with him willingly at first and then dropped and sat on the ground.
Supervisor Y said he had her arm and did not release her at first.
Supervisor Y said Youth A got up and away from him and ran into
the bathroom and undressed so he left the unit. Supervisor Y
denied being aggressive with Youth A or dragging her. Supervisor
Y denied drinking prior to being at work and said Youth A made
allegations that he smelled of alcohol, but he stated he does not
drink and denied being under the influence of alcohol.
Video Reviewed:
Video footage of August 27, 2024, 10:38pm, unit five was
reviewed. Supervisor Y is seen walking into the unit and across
the room to where Youth A is standing. Supervisor Y places his
hands on the back of Youth A’s upper arms and turns her and they
both start walking to the front door on unit five. Youth A is seen
dropping her buttock down to the ground and sat on her bottom
while Supervisor Y maintains his hands on the back of Youth A’s
upper arms. Supervisor Y moves his right hand to Youth A’s back
and attempts to stand her up however Youth A does not get up.
Supervisor Z walks over to them and takes Youth A’s right upper
arm while Supervisor Y has Youth A’s left upper arm and they
attempt to stand her up however Youth A continues to be in the
sitting position with her bottom on the floor. Supervisor Y is seen
with is left hand holding Youth A’s left wrist and his right hand
under Youth A’s right armpit and begins to walk towards the door
while Supervisor Z is still reaching for a hold of Youth A’s right arm.
Supervisor Y pulls Youth A several feet towards the front door as
she is sliding on her bottom. Supervisor Y is seen pulling Youth A
towards the door by her wrist until Youth D comes from another
part of the room and runs up to Supervisor Y and pushes
Supervisor Y away from Youth A and pulls Youth A’s arm away
from Supervisor Y. Supervisor Y and Supervisor Z are seen
releasing Youth A, Youth A gets up and is seen running into the
bathroom. Supervisor Y pushes Youth D with his forearm to move
her away from him. Supervisor Y and Supervisor Z are seen
leaving the unit, while Staff 1 and Staff 2 remain on the unit.
Documents Reviewed:
• Wolverine Human Services Policy for Prohibited
Interventions was reviewed. The policy states staff are not
allowed to use “physical discipline inflicted in any manner”
21

and “unwarranted use of invasive procedures and activities
as a disciplinary action.
• Wolverine Human Services Grievance from completed by
Youth A on 8/27/2024. Youth A reported Supervisor Y “did
not follow protocol and grabbed [Youth A] arms and drug
me across the room. While that was happening I smelt an
alcohol beverage on [Supervisor Y]. [Youth A] arm was red
and I told [Supervisor Y] that I smelt alcohol on his breath.”
Findings from the grievance was completed by Director and
included “[Supervisor Y] preformed an unwarranted
restraint, footage reviewed, and accountability will be
handled by [Director].”
Analysis The agency is in non-compliance as per video review, Supervisor
Y dragged Youth A across the floor several feet by her right arm.
Conclusion Repeat Violation Established
SIR 2023C0000117 dated 3/7/2023, CAP Approved 4/27/2023
SIR 2023C0000039 dated 5/12/2023, CAP Approved 6/29/2023
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
